Award.AwardTitle: Community of Math and Computer Inspired Scholars (MCIS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
As a means to increase the number of students who complete associate's degrees in STEM disciplines and either transfer into baccalaureate programs or go directly into the STEM workforce, the Community College of Baltimore County (CCBC) will provide student support through the Community of Math and Computer Inspired Scholars (MCIS) program. Leveraging existing partnerships with employers of STEM graduates, the Baltimore County Public Schools and four-year institutions, the MCIS program will create effective pathways from high school through employment, upon successful completion of a degree in a STEM field. As individuals from underrepresented minority groups comprise nearly half of the student population at CCBC, the MCIS program will contribute to enhancing diversity in the STEM professional workforce.

From a technical standpoint, the MCIS program will provide 25 scholarships each semester to students who demonstrate financial need, possess high academic potential and are enrolled full-time in the STEM disciplines of Engineering, Engineering Technology, Mathematics, Physics, Computer Science, Information Technology and Network Technology. In addition to the financial support through the S-STEM scholarships, students in the MCIS program will receive a personal faculty mentor to provide academic and professional advising, opportunities to network with STEM professionals, supplemental instruction, and special courses in spatial skills development. Through the use of institutional research data and student surveys, outcomes to be measured include the impact of the project on the enrollment, academic performance, retention and graduation of students from the MCIS program, student perceptions of STEM, employment secured by program graduates and successful transfers to four-year institutions.

Institution.Name: Community College of Baltimore County, Essex

Performance_Institution.Name: Community College of Baltimore County, Essex

POR.DRECONTENT:
From Fall 2014 through Spring 2018, 101 full-time students majoring in certain STEM fields at the Community College of Baltimore County (CCBC) received S-STEM scholarships for one or more semesters through the NSF-funded Community of Math and Computer Inspired Scholars (MCIS) project. 

Although there were 8 eligible associate's degree programs for MCIS, over half of the 101 awardees were in Computer Science or Engineering programs.  Thirty-four percent of the 101 awardees were female. Minority groups that have been underrepresented in STEM fields nationally were represented among the 101 MCIS awardees in proportions close to their population percentage at CCBC.  Namely, 38% self-identified as white, 37% as black, 20% as Asian, 5% as Multiple Races, and 1% as Hawaiian/Pacific Islander.  Among all awardees, 5% were Hispanic/Latino.

Each awardee was paired with a faculty mentor from his/her major field, or a closely related field.  Awardees completed a mentoring agreement that they reviewed with their mentor/  Mentors maintained a mentor log documenting mentor/mentee meetings and detailing actions the scholar needed to take before the next meeting. An eventual total of 22 faculty served as mentors.

Other interventions were incorporated into the MCIS program and contributed to increased retention and degree completion.  Awardees were asked to attend 4 workshops each semester which were also attended by faculty mentors.  Workshops focused on STEM programs, guest speakers from STEM fields, resume writing, panels of awardees who had already transferred to 4-year institutions, as well as icebreakers and team-building activities. The MCIS program encouraged awardees to continue their STEM studies at 4-year institutions.  As stated in the project proposal, 20% of scholarship funds were made available to MCIS awardees who had transferred to 4-year institutions after earning an associate's degree or at least 45 credits in an MCIS-eligible program at CCBC.

MCIS awardees have been highly successful in graduating with associate's degrees and/or transferring to 4-year institutions where 38 awardees to date have earned bachelor's degrees, and another 27 awardees are now actively pursuing STEM bachelor's degrees at their 4-year transfer institutions. The transfer rate to 4-year institutions is 84% for black awardees and 82% for white awardees. Black awardees have a slightly higher rate of earning bachelor's degrees than white awardees (38% vs. 37%).  Associate degree attainment is higher for white awardees (79%) than for black awardees (73%). Female and male awardees were equally likely to earn associate's degrees (74% vs. 73%). Males were slightly more likely to transfer (84% vs. 82%) to 4-year institutions.  Males were also more likley to earn bachelor's degrees than females (40% vs. 32%). No significant differences were found for these comparative outcomes for awardees by race/ethnicity or gender.  

Thirty-four percent of bachelor's degrees earned by awardees were in various engineering programs. Eighty-nine percent of bachelor's degrees earned by awardees were in various Engineering, Computer Science, Information Systems/Information Technology, Cybersecurity, and Game Design major programs combined.

MCIS scholarship awardees were required to participate in completing the Purdue Spatial Visualization Test: Visualization of Rotations (PSVT:R). Awardees who scored less than 70% on the test were asked to participate in one hour long weekly to bi-weekly spatial skills workshops to practice their visualization skills for the duration of the semester, and were requested to take the PSVT:R again at the end of the semester.  Beginning in the Spring 2016 semester, CCBC was one of the community college partners to the Spatial Skills Instruction Impacts Technology Students (SKIITS) project. As a result, an online version of the test and spatial skills workshops was used, allowing students to attend skills workshops online through Blackboard, face-to-face, or in a blended format. Materials were based on the Spatial Course Learning Resources (Sorby 2009). Initially taking the PSVT:R spatial skills test, only 46.5% of the MCIS awardees scored above the 70% pass rate set for it. After participating in several spatial skills workshops, students on average improved their spatial skill score by 16 percentage points.  MCIS students averaged a 67.6% passing rate overall after re-taking the test.  The spatial skills workshops provided students with additional support, faculty interaction and practice with their 3D visualization skills. 

This NSF grant resulted in 3 peer-reviewed conference papers/abstracts/presentations.  PI, Co-PI, and a faculty collaborator attended several national conferences to present the research results of this project.

From 2012 to 2017 enrollment in STEM associate degree programs at CCBC increased 10% with the largest enrollment increase in the new cybersecurity program.

 


Last Modified: 11/23/2019
Modified by: Sylvia Sorkin

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: From Fall 2014 through Spring 2018, 101 full-time students majoring in certain STEM fields at the Community College of Baltimore County (CCBC) received S-STEM scholarships for one or more semesters through the NSF-funded Community of Math and Computer Inspired Scholars (MCIS) project. Thirty-four percent of the 101 awardees were female. Minority groups that have been underrepresented in STEM fields nationally were represented among the 101 MCIS awardees in proportions close to their population percentage at CCBC. Namely, 38% self-identified as white, 37% as black, 20% as Asian, 5% as Multiple Races, and 1% as Hawaiian/Pacific Islander. Among all awardees, 5% were Hispanic/Latino. Each awardee was paired with a faculty mentor from his/her major field, or a closely related field. An eventual total of 22 faculty served as mentors. Other interventions were incorporated into the MCIS program and contributed to increased retention and degree completion. As stated in the project proposal, 20% of scholarship funds were made available to MCIS awardees who had transferred to 4-year institutions after earning an associate's degree or at least 45 credits in an MCIS-eligible program at CCBC. The spatial skills workshops provided students with additional support, faculty interaction and practice with their 3D visualization skills. This NSF grant resulted in 3 peer-reviewed conference papers/abstracts/presentations. PI, Co-PI, and a faculty collaborator attended several national conferences to present the research results of this project. From 2012 to 2017 enrollment in STEM associate degree programs at CCBC increased 10% with the largest enrollment increase in the new cybersecurity program.
